title: How to find the temperature in a constant volume if the pressure is raised 5x - Quora

response.answer_text: Appling the equation of ideal gas, is a good aproximation: pV=nRT, where p is pressure, v is volume, n is a quantity in Mol, R is a constant and T is the absolute temperature in kelvin. So, if you rase 5x p, and volume is constant, the final absolute temperature will be also 5x the initial temperature. Example: If Ti=26,85C = 300K and Pf=5xPi, then Tf=1500K = 1226,86C Ok, it's only an aproximation.

The Combined Gas Law states that: P1V1/T1 = P2V2/T2 (Temperature in Kelvin) In this case, V1 = V2, so P1/T1 = P2/T2 So if P1 =1 and T1 = 273K then P2 = 5 and T2 = 1365K
